newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES END WEEK FIRMER.
newsitem.headline: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES END WEEK FIRMER.

text.p: Short-term trading rates on Zimbabwe's money market were quoted firmer although the market opened with a cash surplus on Friday, dealers said.

Central Reserve Bank figures indicated a surplus of Z$137.4 million at Thursday's close and the bank auctioned Z$30 million worth of 33-day treasury bills to mop up some of the excesses, at an average yield of 23.22 percent.

This compared with 23.10 percent at an auction for 30-day paper the previous day. Discount houses were trading treasury bills on the secondary market at 22.75 percent and call money was at 21 percent from Thursday's 19 to 20 percentage range.
NCD bills with maturity of 30, 60 and 90 days were being bought at 25 percent from 24 and sold half a percentage point firmer at 23.5.
Bank acceptance bills were quoted at 24 percent from 23.75 percent (buying) and sold at 23 percent, still within Thursday's 22.9 to 23.25 percentage range.
